Nodes.ShortText: Definition: Cause of Itself
Definition: Finite in its kind
Definition: Substance
Definition: Attribute
Definition: Mode
Definition: God
Definition: Free
Definition: Eternity
Axiom: In itself or in another
Axiom: Not conceived through another, through itself
Axiom: Effect from cause
Axiom: Knowledge of effect from knowledge of cause
Axiom: Nothing in common, no knowledge in common
Axiom: True idea agrees with ideato
Axiom: If conceived not existing, then essence not requires existence
Substance prior to modifications
Substances with different attributes have nothing in common
Two things with nothing in common are not cause of each other
Two distinct things must have a difference of attribute or of mode
Not two substances with same nature or attribute
One substance cannot produce another
Nature of a substance is to exist.
Every substance is necessarily infinite
The more reality, the more attributes
Each attribute of a substance, conceived through itself
No attribute of substance implies substance is divisible
Substance absolutely infinite is indivisible
Besides God, no substance can be nor be conceived
Whatever is, is in God
Everything conceived by infinite intellect follows from God's nature
God acts from the laws of his own nature and is not compelled
God alone is a free cause
God is the immanent cause of all things
God is eternal; all His attributes are eternal
The existence and essence or God are one and the same
God is immutable
What follows from God's nature is infinite and exists forever
What follows from an attribute as modified, exists forever and is infinite
Every mode which exists infinitely follows from an attribute or an infinite mode
The essence of things produced by God does not involve existence
God is the efficient cause of the existence and essence of things
Individual things are modifications or modes of God's attributes
God and only God can determine a thing to action
A thing determined to an action by God cannot become indeterminate
Finite things determined to actions by other finite things
In Nature is nothing contingent
Natura naturans/Natura naturata
Actual intellect comprehends attributes of God
The actual intellect must be referred to natura naturata
The will cannnot be a free cause
Will and intellect related as motion and rest
Things are produced by God in the only possible order.
The power of God is His essence itself
Whatever we conceive to be in God's power necessarily exists
Nothing exists from whose nature an effect does not follow
There is nothing by which substance can be produced
No substance is divisible
Thinking things and extended things are attributes or modifications of God
God is cause of  himself, not through anything contingent
God acts only through the perfection of His nature
The existence of God is an eternal truth
God the cause of continued existence of things
God does not act from freedom of will
Definition 'Body'
Definition of 'Essence'
Definition of 'Idea'
Definition of 'Adequate Idea'
Definition of 'Duration'
Definition of 'Reality' and 'Perfection'
Definition of 'Individual Things'
Essence of man does not involve existence
Man thinks
Modes of thought such as love, desire, or the emotions do not exists unless an idea of what is loved or desired also exists, but not conversely
We perceive that a certain body is affected in many ways
No individual things are felt except bodies and modes of thought
Thought is an attribute of God; or God is a thinking thing
Extension is an attribute of God; or God is an extended thing
In god exists the idea of his essence and of all things that follow from it.
The idea of God can be one only
Formal being of ideas recognizes God as cause only qua thinking being.
Modes of an attribute have God as cause only under that attribute
The order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things.
God's power of thinking is equal to his power of acting
The ideas of non-existent things are comprehended in the infinite idea of God
Individual things do not exist unless in God's attributes
Individual thing has god for a cause only as affected by another thing
A knowledge of everything in an individual object exists in God so far as he possesses the idea of the object
The being of substance does not pertain to the essence of man
Essence of man consists of modifications of God's attributes
The actual being of the human mind is the idea of an individual thing actually existing
Human mind is a part of the infinite intellect of God
Whatever happens in the object of the human mind is perceived by the mind
The object of the idea constituting the human mind is a body
Man is composed of mind and body, and the body exists as we perceive it
Human body composed of a number of individual, composite parts
Some body parts are fluid, some soft, some hard
The parts of the body are affected by external bodies
The human body needs for its preservation many other bodies
A fluid part imprints upon a soft part
The body can move and arrange external bodies
The human mind is adapted to the perception of many things
The idea which constitutes the formal being of the human mind is composed of many ideas
The idea of every way in which human body is affected involves the nature of the body and external body
The human mind perceives the nature of many bodies and of its own body
The ideas we have of external bodies indicate the constitution of our own body
The mind will regard as present and existing whatever affects its body
The mind can contemplate external things when they are no longer present
When the mind is affected by two bodies, imagining one causes remembering the other
The human mind does not know the human body itself except through ideas of the body's modifications
There exists in God the idea of the human mind, related to Him as is the idea of the human body
God's idea of the mind is united to the mind in the same way as the mind is united to the body
The human mind perceives both the modifications of the body and also the ideas of those modifications
The mind does not know itself except insofar as it perceives the ideas of modifications of the body
The human mind does not involve an adequate knowledge of the parts of the body
The idea of each modification of the body does not involve an adequate knowledge of an external body
The human mind perceives no external body as existing except through ideas of modifications of its body
Insofar as the human mind imagines an external body, insofar it has not an adequate knowledge of it.
The idea of any modification of the body does not inolve an adequate knowledge of the human body itself
The ideas of the modifications of the human body, in the human mind, are not clear and distinct
The idea of the idea of a modification of the body does not inolve an adequate knowledge of the mind
The mind, when it perceives things in the order of Nature, has no adequate knowledge
We can have only an inadequate knowledge of the duration of our body
We can have only an inadequate knowledge of the duration of external things
All ideas, insofar as they are related to God, are true
In ideas, there is nothing positive on account of which they are called false
Every idea in us which is absolute, that is to say adequate and perfect, is true
Falsity consists in the privation of knowledge involved in mutilated and confused ideas
Inadequate and confused ideas follow by the same necessity as adequate ideas
What is common to everything and equally in part and whole forms the essence of no individual thing
What is equally in part and whole can only be adequately conceived
Some ideas are common to all men, and must be clearly and distinctly perceived by all
The mind will have an adequate idea of what is common and proper to the human body
The more things the body has in common with other bodies, the more the mind will be adapted to perceive
The consequences of adequate ideas are adequate
Definition of Knowledge from vague experience (2P40Note2)
Definition of Knowledge of the first kind (2P40Note2)
Definition of Reason, or knowledge of the second kind(2P40Note2)
Definition of Intuitive Science or knowledge of the third kind (2P40Note2)
Knowledge of the first kind is the cause of falsity; others, true
Knowledge of the second kind teach us to distinguish true from false
Whoever has a true idea knows that he has a true idea and cannot doubt the truth of the thing
It is not the nature of reason to consider things as contingent, but as necessary
Through imagination alone we regard things as contingent
It is the nature of reason to perceive things under a certain form of eternity
Every idea of any body or actually existing individual thing involves the eternal essence of God
The knowledge of God's essence which idea involves is adequate and perfect
The human mind possess an adequate knowledge of the eternal essence of God
In the mind there is no free will
Volition or affirmation and negation except what an idea involves
The will and the intellect are one and the same
Formal being of things not modes of thought but as shown
When body a affects body b, all modes follow from nature of a and b (Axiom 1 After 2 Lemma 3)
When a body strikes against another, angle of reflection equals angle of incidence (Axiom 2 After II Lemma 3)
Changability of bodies depends on adjoining surfaces (Axiom 3 After Lemma 3)
Definition of 'Mutually United' (After Lemma 3)
All individual things are contingent and corruptible
Adequate/Inadequate cause:  effect clearly understood by means of the cause
We act when we are adequate cause
Emotion: modifications of the body that alter the power of acting
The human body can be affected in many ways that alter its power of acting
The human body is capable of suffering many changes and retaining traces of objects
Our mind acts at times and at times suffers
Mind subject to passions in proportion to its inadequate ideas; it acts in proportion to adequate ideas
The body cannot determine the mind to thought; nor can the mind determine the body to motion or rest
The actions of the mind arise from adequate ideas alone; passive states depend on inadequate ideas
A thing cannot be destroyed except by an external cause
Insofar as one thing is able to destroy another, they are of contary natures
Each thing, insofar as it is in itself, endeavors to persevere in its being
The effort by which each thing endeavors to persevere in its own being is nothing but the actual essence of the thing itself
The effort by which each thing endeavors to persevere in its own being does not involve finite but indefinite time
The mind endeavors to persevere in its being for an indefinite time, and is conscious of this effort
There can be no idea in the mind which excludes the existence of the body, for such an idea is contrary to the mind
If anything increases, helps, or limits our body's power of action, the idea of that thing increases, diminishes, helps, or limits our mind's power of thought.
The mind endeavors as much as possible to imagine those things which increase or assist the body's power of acting
Whenever the mind imagines those things which lessen or limit the body's power of action, it endeavors as much as possible to recollet what excludes the existence of those things
The mind is averse to imagine those things which lessen or hinder its power and that of the body
If the mind at any time has been simultaneously affected by two emotions, whenever it is afterwards affected by one, it will be affected by the other
Anything may be accidentally the cause of joy, sorrow, or desire
The fact that we have contemplated a thing with an emotion of joy or sorrow, of which it is not the efficient cause, is a sufficient reason for being able to love or hate it
We will love or hate whatever resembles something that usually affects the mind with joy or sorrow
If we imagine that x usually affects us with sorrow and x resembles y, which affects equally with joy, we shall both love and hate x.
A man is affected by the image of a past or future thing with the same joy or sorrow as the image of a present thing.
He who imagines that what he loves is destroyed will sorrow; imagining it preserved, will rejoice
He who imagines that what he hates is destroyed will rejoice
If we imagine that a person affects with joy a thing we love, we shall be affected with love toward him
If we imagine what we hate is affected with sorrow, we will rejoice.  Our emotions are inversely proportional to the joy or sorrow in the hated object.
He who imagines that what he loves is affected with joy or sorrow will also be affected with joy or sorrow, and these emotions will be proportional to their status in the beloved.
If we imagine that a person affects with joy a thin we hate, we are affected with hatred toward him, and conversely
We endeavor to affirm, both concerning ourselves and the beloved object, which we imagine will affect us or the object with joy; and conversely
If we hate a thing, we endeavor to affirm concerning it whatever will affect it with sorrow, and to deny what will give it joy
Although we may not have been moved toward a thing by any emotion, if it is like ourselves, we will echo its emotions
If a person produces joy in a thing like us, we will be affected with love toward him; and conversely
If we pity a thing, the fact that its misery affects us with sorrow will not make us hate it
If we pity a thing, we shall endeavor as much as possible to free it from its misery
We endeavor to bring into existence everything which we imagine conduces to joy and to remove or destroy what is opposed to it
We shall endeavor to do everything which we imagine men will look upon with joy, and conversely
If a person has done anything which he imagines will affect other with joy, he will be joyful, and ill think himself as cause
If we imagine others love what we love, we will love those things more steadily, and conversely
Each man endeavors to make others love what he loves and hate what he hates.
If we imagine a peson enjoys a thing that only one can possess, we will try to prevent his possessing it.
If we love something like ourselves, we strive to make it love us in return
The greater the emotion with which we imagine a beloved object is affected by us, the greater will be our self-exaltation
If I love x, and y love x more, I will hate x and envy y.
Whoever recollects a thing with which he was once delighted will wish to possess it with every condition that existed formerly
If a lover discovers that one condition is missing, he will be sad
The desire which springs from sorrow or joy, hatred or love, is greater in proportion as the emotion is greater
If we cease to love something, we will hate it more than if we had never loved it.
If a man hates another, he will endeavor to do him evil unless he fears a greater evil will arise for himself; and conversely
If we imagine that we are hated by another without having given him cause, we shall hate him in return
If x love y and imagines that y hates x, we will be agitated with both love and hatred
If we imagine that an evil has been brought on us by a man toward who we have had no emotion, we will try to return evil to him
If we imagine we are beloved without having cause, we shall love him in return
If we imagine we are loved by someone we hate, we will be agitated by both love and hatred
If, moved by lover or hope of self-exaltation, we have conferred a favor, we shall be sad if we see the favor is received with ingratitude
Hatred is increased through return of hatred, but may be destroyed by love
Hatred which is altogether overcome by love passes into love, and love is therefore greater than hatred had not preceded it.
If we imagine that any one like ourselves is affected with hatred toward an object like ourselves which we love, we shall hate him.
If we have been affected with joy or sorrow by a foreigner, and if our joy or sorrow is accompanied with the idea of this person as cause, we love no only him, but the nation to which he belongs
The joy which arises from our imagining that what we hate has been destroyed or has been injured is not unaccompanied with some sorrow
Love and hatred toward any object are destroyed if the love or hatred be joined to the idea of another cause.
For the same reason, love or hatred toward an object we imagine to be free must be greater than toward an object under necessity
Anything may be accidentally the cause either of hope or fear
Different men may be affected by one and the same object in different ways, and the same may be affected differently at different times.
An object which we have seen before together with other objects, or which is very like them, will not be comtemplated as much as something peculiar
When the mind contemplates itself and its own power of acting, it rejoices; and it rejoices in proportion to the distinctness with which it imagines itself and its power of action
The more a man imagines that he is praised by others, the more is his joy strengthened.
The mind endeavors to imagine those things only which posit its power of acting
When the mind imagines its own weakness, it necessarily sorrows
This sorrow is strengthened in proportion as the mind imagines itself blamed by others
Noone envies the virtue of a person who is not his equal
There are as many kinds of emotions or derivitives of joy, sorrow and desire, as there are kinds of objects by which we are affected
The emotion of one person differs from the corresponding emotion of another as much as the essence of the one differs from the other
Besides the joys and sorrows which are passive, there are other emotions of joy and sorrow which are related to us in so far as we act.
Among the emotions which are related to the mind insofar as it acts, there are none which are not related to joy or desire
Definition of desire
Definition of joy
Definition of sorrow
Definition of astonishment
Definition of contempt
Definition of love
Definition of hatred
Definition of inclination
Definition of aversion
Definition of devotion
Definition of derision
Definition of hope
Definition of fear
Definition of confidence
Definition of despair
Definition of gladness
Definition of remorse
Definition of commiseration
Definition of favor
Definition of indignation
Definition of overestimation
Definition of contempt
Definition of envy
Definition of compassion
Definition of self-satisfaction
Definition of humility
Definition of repentance
Definition of pride
Definition of despondency
Definition of self-exaltation
Definition of shame
Definition of regret
Definition of emulation
Definition of thankfulness or gratitude
Definition of benevolence
Definition of anger
Definition of vengeance
Definition of cruelty
Definition of fear
Definition of audacity
Definition of pusillanimousity
Definition of consternation
Definition of courtesy or moderation
Definition of ambition
Definition of luxuriousness
Definition of drunkenness
Definition of avarice
Definition of lust
Definition of good
Definition of evil
Definition of contingent
Definition of possible
Definition of contrary emotions
Definition of emotion felt toward a thing future, present or past
Definition of 'end for which we do something' …appetite
Defintion of virtue or power
Each thing in nature is surpassed in strength by some other thing, which can destroy it
Nothing positive contained in a false idea is removed by the presence of the true insofar as it is true
We suffer in so far as we are a part of nature, which part cannot be conceived by itself nor without other parts
The force by which man perseveres in existence is limited and infinitely surpassed by the power of external causes
It is impossible that a man not be a part of Nature and that he should suffer no changes but which follow from his own nature
The force and increase of a passion and its perseverance in existence are not limited by the power by which we endeavor to persevere in existence, but by the power of the external cause
A man is always subject to passions, and he accommodates himself to it as far as the nature of things requires
The other actions or power of a man may be so far surpassed by the force of a passion or emotion that the emotion may obstinately cling to him
An emotion cannot be restrained nor removed unless by an opposed and stronger emotion
Knowledge of good or evil is nothing by an emotion of joy or sorrow in so far as we are conscious of it
If we imagine the cause of an emotion to be actually present with us, that emotion will be stronger than if we imagined the cause not to be present
The image of a past or future object is weaker than the image of a present object; and ceterus paribus, the emotion toward it is weaker as well
We are affected more strongly by a future object that we imagine is near than by one more distant, and similarly for past objects
The emotion toward an object we imagine as necessary is stronger than toward an object possible or contingent
The emotion toward an object we know does not exist in the present, and which we imagine as possible is stronger than the emotion toward a contingent object
The emotion toward an object which we know does not exist as paresnt, and which we imagine as contingent is much weaker than toward an object imagined to be present
The emotion toward a contingent object which we know does not exist in the present is much weaker than the emotion toward a past object.
No emotion can be restrained by the true knowledge of good and evil in so far as it is true, but only in so far as it is considered as an emotion
Desire that arises from a true knowledge of good and evil can be extinguished or restrained by many other desires
The desire that springs from a knowledge of good and evil can be easily extinguished or restrained, insofar as this knowledge is connected with the future
The desire that springs from a true knowledge of good and evil can be still more easily restrained when it is connected with objects which are contingent
The desire that springs from joy, other things being equal, is stronger than that which springs from sorrow.
According to the laws of his own nature, each person necessarily desires that which he considers to be good and avoids what he considers to be evil.
The more a person strives and is able to seek his own profit, the more virtue does he possess; on the other hand, so far as he neglects is own profit, he is impotent
No one can desire to be happy, to act well and live well, who does not at the same time desire to be, to act, and to live…that is, to actually exist.
No virtue can be conceived prior to this, namely the endeavor for self-preservation
A man cannot be absolutely said to act in conformity with virtue except in so far as he is determined because he understands
No one endeavors to preserve his own being formt he sake of another object
To act absolutely in conformity with virtue is, in us, nothing but acting, living, and preserving our being as reason directs from the ground of seeking our own profit.
All efforts which we make through reason are nothing but efforts to understand; and nothing is adjudged profitable except that which conduces to understanding
We do not know that anything is certainly good or evil except that which actually conduces to understanding, or which can prevent us from understanding
The highest good of the mind is the knowledge of God, and the highest virtue of the mind is to know God

No individual object whose nature is altogether different from our own can either help or restrain our power of acting; absolutely nothing can be to us either good or evil unless it possesses something in common with ourselves
Nothing can be evil through that which it possesses in common with our nature, but in so far as a thing is evil to us is it contrary to us.
Insofar as an object agrees with our nature, is it necessarily good.
The more an object agrees with our nature, the more profitable it is to us…that is, the better for us.
Insofar as men are subject to passions, they cannot be said to agree in nature
Men may differ in nature from one another insof as they are agitated by emotions which are passions and insofar also as one and the same man is agitated by passions, he is changeable and inconstant
Insofar as men are agitated by emotions which are passions, they can be contrary to one another
Sofar as men live in conformity with the guidance of reason, insofar only do they always necessarily agree in nature
There is no single thing in Nature that is more profitable to man than a man who lives according to the guidance of reason
When each man seeks most that which is profitable to himself, then are men most profitable to one another
The highest good of those who follow after virtue is common to all, and all may equally enjoy it.
God, a substance, necessarily exists
Favor is not opposed to reason but agrees with it, and may arise from it
What disposes the human body to be affected in many ways, or which renders it capable of affecting external bodies in many ways is profitable to man.
Whatever is effective to preserve the propostion of motion and rest which the parts of the human body bear to each other is good, and contrarywise
Whatever conduces to the universal fellowship of men is profitable, and contrarywise
Joy is not directly evil but good; sorrow, on the other hand, is directly evil.
Cheerfulness can never be excessive, but is always good; melancholy, on the contrary, is always evil
Pleasurable excitement may be excessive and an evil; and pain may be good insofar as pleasurable excitement or joy is evil
Love and desire may be excessive
Hatred can never be good
Envy, mockery, contempt, anger, revenge, and the other emotions which are related to hatred are evil.
Whatver we desire because we are affected by hatred is base and unjust in the State
He who lives according to the guidance of reason strives as much as possible to repay hatred, anger, or contempt of other with love or generosity
The emotions hope and fear cannot be good of themselves
The emotions of overestimation and contempt are always evil
Overestimation easily renders the man who is overestimated proud
Pity in a man who lives according to the guidance of reason is in itself evil and unprofitable
To all actions to which we are determined by an emotion wherein the mind is passive we may, without the emotion, be determined by reason
Self-satisfaction may arise from reason, and the self-satisfaction alone which arises from reason is the highest that can exist
Humility is not a virtue, that is to say, it does not spring from reason
Repentance is not a virtue, that is to say, it does not spring from reason; on the contrary, the man who repends of what he has done is doubly writched or impotent
The greatest pride or the greatest despondency is the greatest ignorance of one's self
The greatest pride or despondency incates the greatest impotence of mind
The proud and desponding are, above all others, subject to emotions
The proud man loves the presence of parasites or flatterers, and hates that of the noble-minded
Self-exaltation is not opposed to reason, but may spring from it
The desire that arises from joy or sorrow, which is related to one or to some, but not to all, the parts of the body, has no regard to the profit of the whole man
A desire which springs from reason can never be in excess
Insofar as the conception of an object is formed by the mind according to the dictate of reason, the mind is equally affected, whether the idea be that of something past, present, or future
He who is led by fear and does what is good in order that he may avoid what is evil is not led by reason
The knowledge of evil is inadequate knowledge
According to the guidance of reason, of two things which are good, we shall follow the greater good, and of two evils, the lesser
According to the guidance of reason, we shall seek the greater future good before that which is leas and present; and contrarywise
A free man thinks of nothing less than of death, and his wisdom is not a meditation upon death, but upon life
According to the guidance of reason, we shall follow a lesser evil for the sake of a greater good, and a lesser good which is the cause of a greater evil we shall neglect

According to the guidance of reason, we shall seek the lesser present evil which is the cause of the greater future good, and the lesser present good which is the cause of a greater future evil we shall neglect
If men were born free, they would form no conception of good and evil so long as they were free
The virtue of a free man is seen to be as great in avoiding danger as in overcoming it
The free man who lives amongst those who are ignorant strives as much as possible to avoid their favors
None but those who are free are very grateful to one another
A free man never acts deceitfully, but always honorably
A man who is guided by reason is freer in a State where he lives according to the common laws than he is in solitude, where he obeys himself alone
A man is necessarily always subject to passions
The endeavor after self-preservation is the primary and only foundation of virtue
A man who lives according to the dictates of reason endeavors as much as possible to prevent himself from being touched by pity
If two contrary actions be excited in the same subject, a change must necessarily take place in both, or in one, until they cease to be contrary
The power of an emotion is limited by the power of its cause, insofar as the essence of the emotion is manifested or limited by the essence of the cause itself
As thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged and connected in the mind, exactly so are the modifications of the body or the images of things arranged and connected in the body
If we detatch a perturbation of the mind or an emotion from the thought of an external cause and connect it with other thoughts, then the love or hatred toward the external cause will be destroyed
An emotion which is a passion ceases to be a passion as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea of it
There is no modification of the body of which we cannot form some clear and distinct conception
An emotion toward an object which we do not imagine as necessary, possible, or contingent, but which we simply imagine is, other things equal, the greatest of all
Insofar as the mind understands all things as necessary, so far has it greater power over the emotions, or suffers less from them.
The emotions which spring from reason or which are excited by it are, if time be taken into account, more powerful than those which are related to individual objects which we contemplate as absent
The greater the number of the causes which simultaneously concur to excite any emotion, the greater it will be
From the third kind of knowledge necessarily springs the intellectual love of God
The intellectual love of God which arises from the third kind of knowledge is eternal
The mind is subject to emotions which are related to passions only so long at the body exists
No love except the intellectual love is eternal

If we are affected by an emotion which is related to many and different causes which the mind contemplates at the same time with the emotion itslef, we are less injured, suffer less from it, and are less affected toward each cause
So long as we are not agitated by emotions which are contrary to our nature, do we possess the power of arranging and connecting the modifications of the body according to the order of the intellect
The greater the number of objects to which an image is related, the more constant is it, or the more frequently does it present iself, and the more does it occupy the mind
The images of things are more eaily connected with those images which are related to things which we clearly and distinctly understand than with any others
The greater the number of other things with which any image is connected, the more frequently does it present itself
The mind can cause all the modifications of the body or of the images of things to be related to the idea of God
He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and his emotions loves God, and loves Him better the better he understands himself and his emotions
This love of God above everything else ought to occupy the mind
God is free from passions, nor is He affected with any emotion of joy and sorrow
No man can hate God
Love of God cannot be turned into hatred
He who loves God cannot strive that God should live him in return
This love of God cannot be defiled either by the emotion of envy or jealousy, but is the more strengthened, the more people we imagine to be connected with God by the same bond of love
The mind can imagine nothing, nor can it recollect anything that is past, except while the body exists
In God, nevertheless, there necessarily exists an idea which expresses the essence of this or that human body under the form of eternity
The human mind cannot be absolutely destroyed with the body, but something of it remains which is eternal
The more we understand individual objects, the more we understand God
The highest effort of the mind and its highest virtue is to understand things by the third kind of knowledge
The better the mind is adapted to understand things by the third kind of knowledge, the more it desires to understand them by this kind of knowledge
From this third kind of knowledge arises the highest possible peace of mind
The effort or the desire to know things by the third kind of knowledgte cannot arise from the first kind, but may arise from the second kind of knowledge

Everything which the mind understands under the form of eternity, it understands not because it conceives the present actual existence of the body, but because it coneives the essence of the body under the form of eternity
Our mind, insofar as it knows itself and the body under the form of eternity, necessarily has aknowledge of God, and knws that it is in God and is conceived through Him
The third kind of knowledge depends upon the mind as its formal cause, insofar as the mind itself is eternal
We delight in whatever we understand by the third kind of knowledgte, and our delight is accompanied with the idea of God as its cause
God loves himself with an infinite intellectual love

The intellectual love of the mind toward God is the very love with which He loves Himself, not insofar as He is infinite, but in so far as He can be manifested through the essence of the human mind considered under the form of eternity
God, insofar as He loves Himself, love men, and consequently that the love of God toward men and the intellectual love of the mind toward God are one and the same thing
There is nothing in Nature which is contrary to this intellectual love, or which can negate it
The more objects the mind understands by the second and third kinds of knowledge, the less it suffers from those emotions which are evil, and the less it fears death
He who possess a body fit for many things possesses a mind of which the greater part is eternal
The more perfection a thing possesses, the more it acts and the less it suffers; and conversely, the more it acts, the more perfect it is
That part of the mind which abides, whether great or small, is more perfect than the other part

Even if we did not know that our mind is eternal, we should still consider as of primary importance piety and religion and absolutely everything which in the Fourth Part we have shown to be related to strength of mind and generosity

Blessedness is not the reward of virtue but is virtue itself; nor do we delight in blessedness because we restrain our lusts, but, on the contrary, because we delight in it, therefore are we able to restrain them
God is cause through Himself, and not through that which is contingent
God is absolutely the first cause
The good which every one who follows after virtue seeks for himself he will desire for other men; and his desire on their behalf will be greater in proportion as he has greater knowledge of God
